Employees within an organisation are termed as valuable resources and these resources constitute a source of sustained competitive advantage (Vaiman 2012 cited in Bashir et.al. (2021). Employee resourcing aspect takes a look on the crucial attributes of knowledge, skills and abilities of the organisational talents and ensures that the organisations gets them right the first time. The RBV theory further explains how a firm can perform better when it combines its unique resources to drive all the areas of the organisation which results to a sustainable competitive advantage through the adoption of strategies (Oga & Chima, 2020). The RBV theory further explains that organisations competitive advantage can only be maintained through possession of unique resources which can also provide superior performance at the same time and which can only be arrived at though talent management of the individual employees (Wright, 2019). The RBV theory emphasizes that organisations should add more value to their resources in a manner that is unique and not easy for competitors to imitate (Ling & Jaw, 2019).  It is in this view that Robinson (2019) observed that when employees are developed they become more committed hence becoming unique assets to the organisation by enabling the organisation to have an edge over the competitor. The strength of RBV theory is that it puts stress on exploring how employees as resources are generated, and how their unique talents are maintained and developed for employee performance, hence, being a relevant theory for this current study.
RBV theory therefore advocates for the management the employees talents which results to getting the resources that qualify to be sources of competitive advantage which must be rare, strategic, inimitable, non-substitutable, appropriate and immobile which can only be achieved by developing the employees’ talent (Snell, 2017). Public and private organisation should advocate for management of their unique talents (Carthigh, 2019) through a wider understanding of resource base theory and its significance. The theorist  suggest to  the managers to develop unique resources and assumes that the managers have the capability of  developing such resources which is an elution of the powers that the managers have and further over estimating the managers capability to control human resources or even predict the future business fortune. Although resource base theory emphasizes on the attraction, retention and management of the most competent workforce but has been criticized on the premises that very little has been explored in relation to which exact practices the theorists would advocate to be embraced for maintaining the talents for long in the workplace (Armstrong, 2012). RBV theory lacks a lot of managerial implication (Wright, McMahan & McWilliams, 2009). Notwithstanding, the major thrust of this theory is relevant to this study.

Workers within a company are often referred to as invaluable assets, and these assets form the basis of a lasting competitive edge (Vaiman 2012 in Bashir and others, 2021). When examining the employee resourcing side, there's a focus on the essential characteristics of knowledge, skills, and abilities of the company's workforce, emphasizing the importance of achieving these attributes correctly from the outset. The Resource-Based View (RBV) theory elaborates on how an organization can outperform others by leveraging its distinctive resources across all operational facets, thus achieving a sustainable competitive advantage through strategic implementations (Oga & Chima, 2020). Moreover, the RBV theory posits that an organization’s competitive edge is preserved by having unique resources that concurrently offer superior performance and are harnessed through effective talent management of its employees (Wright, 2019). The RBV theory underlines the importance for organizations to enhance their resources in ways that are distinct and challenging for rivals to replicate (Ling & Jaw, 2019). From this perspective, Robinson (2019) noted that through the development of employees, they become more devoted, thereby transforming into distinct assets that provide the company with a superiority over competitors. The essence of the RBV theory lies in its focus on the creation, preservation, and enhancement of employees' unique abilities for improved performance, making it a pertinent theory for this analysis.

Consequently, the RBV theory promotes the management of employees’ talents, leading to attaining resources characterized as rare, strategic, inimitable, non-substitutable, suitable, and immovable, achievable solely through nurturing the employees' talents (Snell, 2017). Organizations, both public and private, are encouraged to manage their distinctive talents (Carthigh, 2019) by thoroughly comprehending the resource-based theory and its importance. The theory prompts managers to cultivate unique resources and presupposes their ability to do so, suggesting an overvaluation of the managerial power to shape human resources and to foresee future business outcomes. Even though the resource-based theory highlights the attraction, retention, and management of supremely skilled employees, it is critiqued for the minimal exploration into the specific tactics theorists recommend for retaining talent within the workplace over time (Armstrong, 2012). The RBV theory is noted for its minimal managerial implications (Wright, McMahan & McWilliams, 2009). Nevertheless, the core argument of this theory remains pertinent to the current study.

The concept of intellectual capital has topped the management agenda in recent years and it was put forward by Adam smith. Plant, machinery and other forms of capital are now recognized to account for only a fraction of an organisation’s wealth. The rest of that wealth is bound up in the knowledge, skills, abilities and intellect of the people of the organisation, and their willingness and ability to apply them in the pursuit of organisational goals (Armstrong, 2010 cited in Oyedeji, 2020). The theory of intellectual capital is closely related to what human resource management practices attempts to achieve in terms of building and maintaining the human capital resources required by the firm (Bridger, 2014). It also encompasses the development of structure to ensure that people work effectively together and that they exchange relevant information and ideas and make the best use of the resources of knowledge possessed by the organisation (Boxall & Purcell, 2015).
Intellectual capital consists of the stocks and flows of knowledge, ability, skill and competencies available to an organisation (Burbach & royle, 2017). These can be regarded as intangible resources which together with tangible resources (money and physical assets) comprise the market or total value generating processes of a firm and are under its control. As described by James (2015), these incorporate the value of all relationships inside and outside the organisation including those with customers and suppliers. They also cover the values attached to such intangibles as goodwill, corporate image and brands.
The three elements of intellectual capital by Vaiman (2002) are human capital, social capital and organisational capital. Human capital at the micro-level refers to the knowledge, skills and abilities of the employees in an organisation and can be made by developing existing staff through training and development or bought by attracting new staff with the skills and knowledge required so as to get the right human capital the first time (Cappelli, 2008). This in addition makes employees feel valued and in return have a sense of commitment in their organisational undertakings. Social capital on the other hand refers to the stocks and flows of knowledge derived from networks of relationships within and outside the organisation. It may also refer to the structure within which human capital is most effectively deployed, and includes the use of communication, involvement and other initiatives to facilitate the exchange of knowledge (Esu, 2019).
Oluyemi and Adeku (2020) defined organisational capital as the institutionalized knowledge possessed by an organisation that is stored in databases and manuals. He in addition says that he prefers the concept of organisational capital to others because it conveys clearly that this is the knowledge that the organisation actually owns. Organisational capital is most likely to be the object of knowledge management systems as organisations strives to find better ways to capture, store and use knowledge effectively (Carins, 2009 cited in Akinremi& Adedeji, 2019).
In addition, in the process of placing and orienting these new hires into the organisation, employees are able to communicate and exchange ideas amongst themselves as a way of exercising the social capital in the organisation. The human resource manager conducts the training need analysis of employees in order to know the employees to be trained and the areas to be trained on so as to instill knowledge, skills and abilities (Lew, 2013).

The notion of intellectual capital has emerged as a primary focus in the realm of management in recent times, with its origination attributed to Adam Smith. It's now acknowledged that an organization's wealth isn't merely derived from tangible assets like plant and machinery, but significantly from the collective knowledge, skills, abilities, and intellectual prowess of its personnel, coupled with their readiness and capability to deploy these in achieving organizational objectives (Armstrong, 2010 as referenced in Oyedeji, 2020). Intellectual capital theory aligns closely with the objectives of human resource management practices, which aim to cultivate and preserve the human capital necessary for the organization's needs (Bridger, 2014). Additionally, it involves creating an organizational structure conducive to effective teamwork and the free exchange of pertinent information and ideas, maximizing the organization's knowledge resources (Boxall & Purcell, 2015).

Intellectual capital is made up of the knowledge, skills, abilities, and competencies an organization possesses (Burbach & Royle, 2017). These intangible assets, in conjunction with tangible assets like financial and physical resources, contribute to a firm's market value and fall under its management. James (2015) elaborated that this includes the worth of all internal and external relationships, encompassing interactions with customers and suppliers, and extends to intangibles like goodwill, corporate identity, and brand values.

According to Vaiman (2002), intellectual capital comprises three components: human capital, social capital, and organizational capital. Human capital pertains to the individual-level attributes of knowledge, skills, and abilities of employees, which can be developed through training or enhanced by recruiting new talent possessing essential skills and knowledge, thereby securing the desired human capital from the outset (Cappelli, 2008). This approach also serves to make employees feel appreciated, fostering their commitment to organizational tasks. Social capital involves the knowledge that emerges from networks of relationships both within and outside the organization. It also refers to the frameworks that enable optimal utilization of human capital, incorporating communication, engagement, and other methods to promote knowledge sharing (Esu, 2019).

Organizational capital, as defined by Oluyemi and Adeku (2020), refers to the institution-specific knowledge contained within databases and manuals, representing the intellectual property of an organization. This form of capital is often targeted by knowledge management systems, aiming to enhance the capture, storage, and application of knowledge (Carins, 2009 in Akinremi & Adedeji, 2019).

Moreover, the integration and orientation of new employees into an organization facilitate the exchange and communication of ideas, leveraging the entity's social capital. The role of a human resource manager in identifying the training needs of staff to impart necessary knowledge, skills, and abilities is crucial in this process (Lew, 2013).

Such trainings if carried out in the right way can be used to create a career path for the employees, which is part of career management. The Human Resource managers also use the information in the database to determine the best kind of rewards to offer to the employees as they perform their duties and contribute to the overall achievement of organisational goals (Robinson, 2019). This theory is relevant to the study as it informs the employee resourcing variable in that organisations are able to identify the best human capital to work with by attracting new staff with the right skills and knowledge. Through the theory, organisations conducts the training need analysis of employees in order to know the employees to be trained and the areas to be trained on so as to instill knowledge, skills and abilities. This leads to enhanced employee performance in organisations.

Properly executed training programs can pave the way for employees' career progression, serving as a cornerstone of career management strategies. Human Resource (HR) managers leverage data within their systems to ascertain the most fitting rewards for employees as a recognition of their job performance and their contributions towards achieving the company's objectives (Robinson, 2019). This concept plays a crucial role in the study as it elucidates the aspect of employee resourcing by enabling organizations to pinpoint the optimal human capital for their operations. It entails attracting new talent equipped with the necessary skills and knowledge. Through this theoretical framework, companies engage in a thorough analysis of training needs among their workforce to identify which employees require training and in what areas, aiming to equip them with essential knowledge, skills, and capabilities. Such initiatives are key to boosting organizational performance by enhancing the competencies of its employees.

The ER theory of motivation propounded by Clayton Alderfer is indeed a reaction of Maslow’s theory. He argued that there are three core needs which he classified as Existence needs, Relatedness and Growth needs (Alderfer, 1972) cited in Adedayo (2017). ER is a motivational construct concerned with understanding the factors that contribute to individual human behaviour. It is one of four content approaches that consider the intrinsic factors that cause a person to take specific actions (Idris, 2014). Such understanding is useful to management students and practitioners seeking to understand and improve performance in the workplace. Existence needs has to do with the satisfaction of basic needs such as food, water, pay and working conditions, they can be classified as physical, safety and material needs. Physiological needs refer to an individual’s pursuit of satisfaction at the vitality level, such as leisure, exercise, sleep, Safety needs mainly refer to the prevention from fear, anxiety, threat, danger, tension, Material needs refer to resources required for an individual’s living, including food and clothing 
The Relatedness needs is similar to the social role needs of Maslow’s theory and they includes social and interpersonal relationship. It also includes sense of security, belonging, and respect. Sense of security involves the mutual trust of humanity. Sense of belonging refers to prevention from all forms of suffering, such as isolation, loneliness and distance. People normally wish to be accepted and become members of a group. The needs for belongingness include love given to others or caring accepted from others. Sense of respect simply means feeling of respect from others, such as popularity, social status, superiority, importance and compliment. Such form of need gives people value to their existence (Ivancevich, 2019).
Finally, the Growth need is intrinsic desire for personal development or making creative productive contribution. It involves needs for self-esteem and self-actualization. The need for self-esteem refers to self-productive effects such as the ability to pursue, to seek knowledge, to achieve, to control, to build confidence, to be independent and to feel competent. Self-actualization refers to self-accomplishments including achieving an individual’s goals and developing his or her personality. The abilities to realize one’s potentials and to support the growth of others are also included. Snell  (2018) argued that if the gratification of a higher level order need is stifled, the desire to satisfy a lower level need increase i.e. frustration, regression and dimension The thrust of the theory is that when needs in a higher category are not met then the individuals redouble the efforts invested in a lower category need. The needs do not have to be met sequentially. The theory is very relevant to this theory because, Vroom’s expectation theory suggested what can be done to motivate employees. It’s been observed that there is a high increase in the level of job performance and reduce employee turnover intentions when employees are properly motivated. A motivated employees’ work attitude is wholesome and tends toward high performance and productivity in the organisation

Clayton Alderfer's ER theory of motivation, developed as a rebuttal to Maslow's hierarchy of needs, postulates that human motivation is driven by three fundamental needs: Existence, Relatedness, and Growth (Alderfer, 1972) as cited by Adedayo (2017). This motivation framework focuses on identifying factors that influence individual behavior. It is one of the content theories emphasizing intrinsic elements that propel individuals towards certain behaviors (Idris, 2014). Such insights prove valuable for management students and practitioners aiming to bolster workplace performance. Existence needs encompass basics like sustenance, hydration, compensation, and working conditions, aligning with physiological, safety, and material requirements. These involve seeking pleasure in activities like leisure and sleep, ensuring personal safety from threats, and securing essentials for living such as food and clothing.

Relatedness needs echo Maslow’s social needs, covering aspects like social bonds and personal relationships. This dimension embraces the quest for a security sense through mutual trust, a sense of belonging to evade isolation, and the need for esteem through acknowledgment from others, such as recognition, status, and validation. These needs affirm one's place and worth within a social context (Ivancevich, 2019).

Growth needs reflect an innate urge for self-improvement and contributing creatively. This category includes desires for self-regard and self-realization, covering the drive for achievement, knowledge acquisition, self-reliance, competence, and realizing individual aspirations and potential. This facet also involves fostering others' development. According to Snell (2018), frustration or obstruction in fulfilling an advanced need intensifies the effort toward satisfying more fundamental needs, suggesting that the gratification of needs doesn't necessarily follow a sequential order but adapts based on circumstances.

The essence of Alderfer's theory highlights the concept that unmet higher-tier needs prompt a revisited focus on more basic categories of need. This nonlinear approach underscores the adaptability of human motivation, aligning with Vroom's expectancy theory, which delves into how to incentivize employees effectively. Observations indicate that well-motivated employees exhibit enhanced job performance and reduced turnover intentions, leading to a generally positive work attitude and heightened organizational productivity and efficiency.

The Expectancy Theory was propounded by Victor H. Vroom. Vroom’s expectancy theory was an attempt to describe how an individual’s motivation to achieve a particular goal or performance target can be explained in terms of what outcome would become beneficial to the individual as a result of achieving that goal and what value is placed on that outcome (Amir, 2015). Vroom's theory is based on the belief that employee’s effort will lead to performance and performance will lead to rewards (Vroom, 1964 cited Anyadike, 2020). Essentially, the expectancy theory argues that the strength of a tendency to act in a certain way depends on the strength of the expectation that the act will be followed by a given outcome and on the attractiveness of that outcome to the individual (Robbins, 1989) cited in Adedayo (2017). According to Idemobi (2010), the Expectancy Theory is a process theory that was developed to basically concentrate on the outcomes. What Vroom explained in his theory is that in order to motivate employees or people, the effort put in by the lecturers, the performance generated and motivation must be linked to one another. According to Vroom, employee’s expectations can affect an individual’s motivation. Therefore, the amount of effort lecturers   exert on a specific task depends on their expectations of the outcome.
According to Robbins (1989), the expectancy theory includes three variables or relationships which are attractiveness, performance-reward linkage and the effort-performance linkage. Attractiveness explains the importance that the individual places on the potential outcome or reward that can be achieved on the job. This considers the unsatisfied needs of the individual. Performance-reward linkage is the degree to which the individual believes that performing at a particular level will lead to the attainment of a desired outcome. Effort-performance linkage explains the perceived probability by the individual that exerting a given amount of effort will lead to performance. These three factors according to Vroom combine and create a “force” which stimulates or motivates an individual to put in effort in order to achieve a level of performance and then obtain end rewards. This type of theory distinguishes between the most motivated, and the least motivated employees (Reed, 2009). Expectancy explains that the belief of a person that his/her effort (E) will result in attainment of desired performance (P) goals. Instrumentally: P->R. the belief of a person that he/she will receive a reward if the performance (P) expectation is met. Valance is then the value of the reward according to the person (is the reward attractive to the person)
The expectancy theory of motivation has been the target of many critics (Cole, 2013). One of the major criticisms was its simplicity. In the sense that it does not explain the different levels of efforts acted out by an individual. There is also the assumption that a reward will entice an employee to expand greater efforts in order to obtain the reward, but neglect the fact that the reward in question could have a negative effect for the individual. For example, a pay increase might push him or her into a higher tax bracket (Lawler, 1967; Porter, 1968 cited in David, 2018). The effectiveness of the expectancy theory from a managerial perspective relies on the manager to make assumptions on the motivational force of the reward for the employee (s). Thus, the use of rewards needs to obey “the law of effect” where: positively rewarded behaviors will have a tendency to augments in frequency, negatively or neutrally reward behaviors will have a tendency to diminish in frequency and the type of reinforcement and its timing will impact the frequency of the behaviour. Thus, a particular reward can fulfill multiple outcomes, consequently adding to the sum of the valences.

Victor H. Vroom's Expectancy Theory is a framework aiming to illustrate how an individual's motivation to reach a specific goal or achievement is influenced by the anticipated benefit of the outcome and the value attributed to it by the individual (Amir, 2015). Rooted in the idea that an employee's effort leads to performance, and performance to rewards (Vroom, 1964 as mentioned by Anyadike, 2020), the theory posits that the likelihood of an individual acting in a certain manner is tied to the expectation of a particular outcome and the desirability of this outcome for the person (Robbins, 1989 in Adedayo, 2017). Idemobi (2010) characterizes the Expectancy Theory as a process-oriented theory, focusing on outcomes and linking the efforts and performance of individuals, such as lecturers, to motivation. Vroom suggests that an employee’s expectations shape their motivation, and thus, the effort they put into a task depends on their anticipated outcomes.

Robbins (1989) outlines three key components or relationships within the expectancy theory: attractiveness, performance-reward linkage, and effort-performance linkage. Attractiveness refers to the value an individual places on the potential reward or outcome achievable through their work, addressing the person’s unmet needs. Performance-reward linkage assesses the extent to which the individual believes that achieving a certain level of performance will result in obtaining a desired outcome. The effort-performance linkage considers the individual’s belief in the likelihood that exerting a particular amount of effort will lead to the anticipated performance. Collectively, these factors generate a motivational "force" encouraging an individual to exert effort to reach a performance level that results in gaining rewards, distinguishing between the most and least motivated employees (Reed, 2009). Essentially, expectancy denotes a person's belief that their effort (E) will achieve desired performance (P) goals, leading to the attainment of rewards (P->R), and valence embodies the attractiveness of the reward to the individual.

However, Vroom's Expectancy Theory has encountered several criticisms, such as its simplicity and failure to account for the varying levels of effort individuals may exert (Cole, 2013). Critics argue that it assumes rewards universally entice employees to exert more effort, without considering how some rewards might negatively impact an individual. For instance, a pay raise could inadvertently result in an employee being moved to a higher tax bracket, presenting a less appealing outcome (Lawler, 1967; Porter, 1968 in David, 2018). The effectiveness of this theory from a managerial standpoint requires assumptions about how motivational a reward is for an employee. The application of rewards should adhere to "the law of effect": behaviors that are positively rewarded are likely to increase in frequency, whereas those that are negatively or neutrally rewarded are likely to decrease. Additionally, the nature and timing of reinforcement influence behavior frequency, with a single reward potentially fulfilling multiple outcomes, thus affecting the overall valence sum.

Adams' Equity Theory, also known as the Equity Theory of Motivation, was propounded in 1963 by John Stacey Adams, a Belgian psychologist known for workplace behaviour. Equity theory of motivation seeks to balance an employee's contribution and output in the workplace. If the employee can strike the correct balance, it will result in a more productive relationship with management.
Equity is the art of one individual being fair and impartial in social interactions with another individual (Adams, 1963 cited in Francis, 2014). It is an art because it requires an individual to have a skill. The skill resists the ease that comes with selfish interests in order to facilitate an effective relationship with another individual’s goals in mind. Adams (1963) cited Haid (2012), posits that Equity is achieved when the ratio of employee outcomes over inputs is equal to other employee outcomes over inputs
Adams' Equity theory states that employees strive for equity between themselves and other workers (Davies, 2010). Equity theory recognizes that individuals are concerned not only with the absolute amount of rewards they receive for their efforts, but also with the relationship of this amount to what others receive. They make judgments as to the relationship between their inputs and outcomes and the inputs and outcomes of others. Based on one’s inputs such as effort, experience, education and competence; one compares outcomes such as salary levels, raises, recognition and other factors.
 When people perceive an imbalance in their input-outcome ratio relative to others, tension is created. This tension provides the basis for motivation, as people strive for what they perceive as equity and fairness (Robbins, 1989 cited in Faruna, 2018). The theory investigates an individual’s perceived fairness of an employment situation and find that there are perceived inequalities, he/she would change behaviour and may go further to take action to seek a redress of the in balance. This redress may be in any of the four ways: increase outputs (by working harder, attend training courses, or go for further education), decrease inputs (by working less, refuse to take as much responsibility, or be so obliging to help others), and increase outcomes (aim for extrinsic benefits such as requesting for more pay, extra holidays etc.) and quit (resign from the job, absenteeism). Equity theory has helped organisation address the issue of injustice, partiality, and unfairness.

John Stacey Adams' Equity Theory, formulated in 1963, is a foundational concept in understanding workplace behavior, specifically focusing on the dynamics of employee motivation through fairness and equity. This theory underscores the importance of achieving a balance between what an employee contributes to their workplace and what they receive in return. When this balance is attained, it fosters a more productive and harmonious relationship between employees and management.

Equity, as Adams described, is the practice of being fair and impartial during social interactions (Adams, 1963 as mentioned in Francis, 2014). It necessitates a skillful approach where an individual resists personal bias and selfish motives to prioritize an effective relationship that considers the objectives of others. According to Adams (cited in Haid, 2012), equity is realized when the ratio of an employee’s outcomes to inputs matches that of their peers.

Adams posited that employees naturally seek parity with their colleagues in terms of rewards and recognition (Davies, 2010). The Equity Theory acknowledges that workers evaluate not just the total rewards they receive but also how these rewards compare to those received by others. This comparison takes into account their own contributions, such as effort, skill, experience, and education, against the rewards received, which may include salary, promotions, and acknowledgment.

When individuals perceive a disparity in the ratio of their contributions to rewards relative to others, it generates tension. This tension acts as a motivational driver, propelling individuals to seek what they perceive as equity and justice (Robbins, 1989 as cited in Faruna, 2018). If an employee perceives an inequity in their work situation, they might alter their behavior to address this perceived imbalance. Actions taken might include increasing their outputs (through additional effort, undergoing training, or further education), reducing their inputs (by diminishing their workload, avoiding responsibilities, or lessening their cooperativeness), seeking to improve their outcomes (negotiating for higher pay or more vacation time), or opting to exit the organization altogether (through resignation or increased absenteeism).

Equity Theory has been instrumental for organizations in recognizing and ameliorating issues related to injustice, bias, and unfair treatment, guiding them in creating workplaces that strive for fairness and equity among employees.

In 2001, Mitchell et al. (2001) introduced a new conceptual framework called job embeddedness. Derived from Lewin's field theory, job embeddedness "represents a broad constellation of influences" (Mitchell et aI. 2001, p. 7) on an employee's intent to stay and can be thought of as "a net or a web in which one can become stuck" (Mitchell et aI., 2001, p. 7).
Mitchell et al. (2001) clarified that "job embeddedness does not cause one to go out and get married, buy a house, or increase linkages with the organisation," but "those activities cause a person to become embedded" (p. 25). They further proposed that job embeddedness represented a unique factor in understanding why people stay at their jobs and discussed ways in which employers can influence employees' embeddedness and propensity to stay. They recommended examining three components-links, fit, and sacrifice-each in an organisational and community context. It is this examination of both the organisation and community that makes job embeddedness unique in helping explain employee retention.
In Mitchell et aI. (2001) original job embeddedness study, the authors used chi square and correlational statistics and found that job embeddedness improved the prediction of turnover over and above that provided by job satisfaction, organisation commitment, and intent to stay (Mitchell et aI., 2001, p. 30). The authors concluded that the job-satisfaction and organisation-commitment frameworks insufficiently explain why people stay in an organisation, because they ignore the effects of an employee's nonwork
The relevance of the theory to the study is that  when  manufacturing industries   are properly  managed  with various  strategies of integrated  talent management  practices involving human resource planning, recruitment and selection of the right candidates for the job,  employee development, provision of corresponding employee rewards  based on their performance, the access and equal opportunity for professional  employee training and development, and the use of   transparent and merit based performance appraisal  for employees, this gesture will no doubt boost their morale and hence enhancing their performance, particularly, manufacturing staff who work in corporate organisation where every minute count for the job productivity of each member staff.  More so, where employees are not denied free access to information, there will be improved in their job performance.
Furthermore, the perception those employees attach to human resource management practices vary depending on employees' interpretations of an employer's underlying motivation (Nishii et al., 2008). Employees respond positively if they believe that the employer is willing to implement a favorable human resources management practices, but are less likely to exhibit positive behaviors if they perceive employers’ adoption of human resources management practices is mostly in the interest of employers (Wright, 2014). Therefore, employees are more likely to interpret supportive human resources management practices as a favour from their organisation and tend to feel obligated to reciprocate the organisation's favour by engaging in positive attitude and   behaviors   towards their jobs.

In 2001, Mitchell and colleagues introduced the concept of job embeddedness, drawing from Lewin's field theory. They portrayed job embeddedness as a comprehensive array of factors influencing an employee's desire to remain in their position, likening it to becoming entangled in a net or web (Mitchell et al., 2001, p. 7). The scholars explained that job embeddedness itself doesn’t directly cause personal life decisions such as getting married or buying a house, but rather these life decisions contribute to an individual's degree of embeddedness (p. 25). Moreover, they suggested that job embeddedness offers a distinctive lens through which to understand employee retention, urging companies to consider the elements of links, fit, and sacrifice within both the organizational and community spheres to enhance employees' inclination to stay.

In their seminal study on job embeddedness, Mitchell et al. employed statistical methods to demonstrate that job embeddedness could predict employee turnover more effectively than traditional indicators such as job satisfaction, organizational commitment, and intent to stay (Mitchell et al., 2001, p. 30). They argued that previous frameworks focusing on job satisfaction and organizational commitment fell short of fully explaining why individuals remain with an organization because they overlooked the impact of an employee's life outside work.

The significance of job embeddedness theory in this context is that when manufacturing industries implement comprehensive talent management strategies – encompassing human resource planning, accurate recruitment and selection, employee development, performance-based rewards, equitable access to professional training, and transparent performance appraisals – employees' morale and performance, particularly in high-stakes corporate environments, are likely to improve. This is especially true when employees are granted open access to information, further boosting job performance.

Moreover, employees’ perceptions of human resource management practices vary based on how they interpret the employer's motivations behind these practices (Nishii et al., 2008). Positive employee responses are more likely when they believe that their employer is genuinely committed to implementing favorable human resources management practices. Conversely, if employees perceive that these practices serve primarily the employers' interests, their reactions may not be as favorable (Wright, 2014). Thus, employees who view supportive human resources management practices as a benefit from their organization may feel a sense of obligation to reciprocate with positive attitudes and behaviors toward their work, fostering a more engaged and committed workforce.

Several empirical studies relating to the influence of integrated talent management strategies on employees’ turnover intentions and job performance have been carried out in public, private and corporate organisations both within and outside the country. Some of them will be reviewed in this section of the study.Bashiret.al. (2021) investigated how talent management practice:  talent selection, talent retention, employee training and talent development trigger corporate performance indicators like product innovation, capacity utilization and customer retention. Respondents were drawn from the management staff of eight commercial banks in Abuja namely; First Bank Plc, Zenith Bank Plc and First City Monument Bank (FCMB). The study found that: there is significant relationship between talent selection and organisational productivity, talent retention plays a vital role on employees’ performance and that; talent development has positive impact on employees’ commitment in the selected commercial banks. Based on the research findings, the researcher recommends that: organisational culture should be defined as employees who fit in with the organisational culture tend to be more productive and in a happy space. Training programs, courses, seminars, classes and workshops should be organized to promote learning and encourage employees to participate and acquire new skills.
Also, Onwuka et.al. (2020) investigated talent management and employees performance in selected public sector firms in Delta State, Nigeria. Sample size was determined using Taro Yamani’s statistical technique. 364 questionnaires were distributed to respondents, out of which 273 questionnaire were returned. Analysis of Variance (ANOVA) was conducted using SPSS-20 to compare different population of mean existing within the groups and between the groups at five point-likert scale. The study found that F-calculated value (73.166) was greater than F-tabulated (2.53) value at 5% significant level in the selected public sector firms. Hence, the null hypothesis was rejected. Study concludes that there is an existence of strong relationship between talent management and employees performance in selected private sector organisation. The study recommended that, organisation should align their talent management system to meet up with their business requirements; and, management should know what factors contribute to difficulties in attraction and retention of employees so that effort should be made to keep various retention factors in balance.
A similar study Agbaeze, Monyei and Agu (2017), was on the impact of talent management strategies on organisational performance in selected deposit money banks in Lagos State, Nigeria. This study identified the impact of talent management strategies on organisational performance in selected deposit money bank in Lagos State, Nigeria. Data were collected using the questionnaire research instrument and interview guide. The sample size of 359 was obtained from the population using Bill Godden’s formula. The study found that succession planning, compensation management, human resource development is the essential strategies that enhances organisational performance. The study recommended that, organisation’s management should ensure that a suitable, effective and consistent succession management is applied by strategically determining, investigating and developing employee to ensure that they are able of filling key positions due to its importance to an organisations survivability and success in the industry.

In the realm of organizational behavior and human resource management, the influence of integrated talent management strategies on employee turnover intentions and job performance has garnered significant attention across public, private, and corporate sectors globally. This section reviews empirical research findings that shed light on this critical area.

Bashiret et al. (2021) delved into how talent management practices—including talent selection, retention, training, and development—impact corporate performance indicators such as product innovation, capacity utilization, and customer retention within the context of eight commercial banks in Abuja, including First Bank Plc, Zenith Bank Plc, and First City Monument Bank (FCMB). The study's results underscored that talent selection is closely linked with organizational productivity, talent retention significantly influences employee performance, and talent development boosts employees' commitment. The researchers suggested fostering an organizational culture where employees align well with the organizational ethos, thereby enhancing productivity and satisfaction. Additionally, they advocated for comprehensive training initiatives to facilitate continuous learning and skill acquisition among employees.

Similarly, Onwuka et al. (2020) explored the relationship between talent management and employee performance in various public sector entities in Delta State, Nigeria. Utilizing Taro Yamane’s statistical technique to determine the sample size, they distributed 364 questionnaires, receiving 273 in return. Employing SPSS-20 for an Analysis of Variance (ANOVA), the study concluded a significant correlation between talent management practices and employee performance, demonstrated by an F-calculated value (73.166) surpassing the F-tabulated (2.53) at a 5% significance level. The recommendation was for organizations to tailor their talent management systems to match business needs and address factors affecting employee attraction and retention.

Agbaeze, Monyei, and Agu (2017) focused on the effects of talent management strategies on organizational performance in selected deposit money banks in Lagos State, Nigeria. Through questionnaires and interviews amongst a 359 sample size, determined via Bill Godden’s formula, the study pinpointed succession planning, compensation management, and human resource development as key strategies enhancing organizational performance. The recommendation laid out by this study emphasized the importance of effective succession management strategies for filling key positions, critical for an organization's longevity and market success.

Collectively, these studies highlight the integral role of strategic talent management in improving organizational performance, employee satisfaction, and retention across different sectors and geographical locations. They advocate for a holistic approach to talent management, stressing the importance of alignment with organizational goals, continuous development, and a supportive culture to maintain a committed and high-performing workforce.

Equally related to the foregoing is a study by Kehinde (2019) who investigated the effect of talent management on company’s performance. The data were obtained from 16 senior managers in Nigeria. Purposive sampling techniques were employed to select respondents. The findings showed that there is a positive impact of talent management on performance of the multinational and the national companies but the small and medium companies have not been gaining from this new technique within the Nigerian business environment. The study recommends that talent management should be used for all categories of staff within the companies that have special talent and that should separate between their talent management scheme and the total human recourses management style of the companies.
In a similar study, Adewoye and Salau (2022) appraised the effect of talent management on Small Scale Enterprises (SMEs) performance in Lagos State, Nigeria. This study adopted the simple random sampling technique on the registered members of National Association of Small and Medium Enterprises, Lagos State chapter. One hundred and eighty-five questionnaires were completed and returned. The principal tools for analysis of data are carried out with the help of regression analysis. The results reveal that that: all the variables of talent management (talent attraction, talent retention and talent development) are positively significant to the performance of SMEs, the study further concludes that SMEs must always attract retain and develop good staff. In the light of the above conclusions, the study recommended that various SMEs associations and should endeavor to include talent management in their training programs. SMEs should also improve on their talent management strategy by attracting, retaining and developing their employee for a better performance. Also, SMEs should align their talent management initiatives with their business goals.
In another study, Makporand Akpoyibo (2021) investigated employees’ talent, and attitude on organisational efficiency. Survey research design was employed for this study, with a population of 192 employees from six selected bottled water manufacturing companies in Edo State, Nigeria. Returned and correctly filled questionnaire was 117, primary data were collected with the help of questionnaire, while data analysis was correlation analysis. The findings revealed that employee’s talent and attitude have a positive and significant relationship on organisational efficiency. The researcher therefore, concluded that employees fit influences organisational efficiency. It was in this context that the researcher recommended that identification of the personal values of prospective employees by management and human resources department during the recruitment and selection process, and performance appraisal that align with the organisational efficiency should be prioritized.
            So also, Akinremi and Adedeji (2019) investigated talent management and the performance employee in selected banks in Akure, Ondo State, Nigeria. The study also investigated the strategies used in retaining talented employee in deposit money banks selected and also examined the factors influencing implementation of talent management policies in deposit money banks. Descriptive statistics and appropriate inferential statistics were employed for the data analysis. The study revealed the strategies used in retaining talented employee in deposit money banks. It shows that compensation and rewards are both financial and nonfinancial in deposit money banks has a mean value of (3.82). Deposit money banks attract and retain key workers by applying total rewards strategy has a mean value of (3.50).According to the result, some of the factors influencing implementation of talent management practices in deposit money banks are; culture and relationship between top management and employee, salary and promotion contribute to retention within the organisation, retention strategy in retaining talented employee, and compensation and reward management policies on employee retention. Test statistics shows that the chi-square value is 106.62, with 4 as the degree of freedom and the significant value is 0.001. Since the significant value is (0.001) is less than level of significant (0.05), the null hypothesis (Ho) is rejected, and alternate hypothesis (Hi) is accepted. Thus, talent management practices implementation has significant effect on employees’ satisfaction in deposit money banks. The study concludes that it is equally of value that organisations should train and retrain their work force to develop needed talent in the staff. The correlation between profitability and talent management cannot be overemphasized. The study recommended that strategies used in retaining talented employee in deposit money banks must be improved upon and must be a long-term focus of every deposit money banks in the study area.

The significance of talent management across different organizational scales and sectors continues to draw academic attention, with several studies highlighting its impact on company performance, employee attitudes, and organizational efficiency.

Kehinde (2019) conducted a study examining the influence of talent management on the performance of companies in Nigeria, focusing on responses from 16 senior managers. The study concluded that while multinational and national companies in Nigeria benefit positively from talent management practices, small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) have yet to fully realize these benefits within the Nigerian business context. The recommendation was for companies to apply talent management across all staff levels, especially those with unique talents, and to distinguish their talent management strategies from their broader human resources management practices.

Adding to the conversation, Adewoye and Salau (2022) assessed how talent management impacts the performance of Small Scale Enterprises (SMEs) in Lagos State, Nigeria. Through a survey of the National Association of Small and Medium Enterprises' registered members, the study found a positive significance between talent management variables (attraction, retention, and development) and SME performance. It recommended that SME associations integrate talent management into their training programs and align it with business objectives to improve overall performance.

Makpor and Akpoyibo (2021) explored the relationship between employees' talents and attitudes towards organizational efficiency within the bottled water manufacturing sector in Edo State, Nigeria. Their research, which applied survey methods and correlation analysis on responses from 192 employees, discovered a positive correlation between talent and attitude and organizational efficiency, suggesting that employee compatibility influences organizational outcomes. They advised that organizations focus on aligning personal values with organizational objectives during recruitment and appraisals.

Furthermore, Akinremi and Adedeji (2019) investigated the effects of talent management on bank employee performance in Akure, Ondo State, Nigeria. The study revealed various strategies banks use to retain talent, including compensation and reward systems. Key findings highlighted the influence of organizational culture and the relationship between management and employees on talent retention. It demonstrated that implementing talent management practices significantly contributed to employee satisfaction in banks. The study stressed the importance of continuous training and the correlation between profitability and efficient talent management, urging banks to focus on long-term retention strategies for their workforce.

Collectively, these studies underscore the critical role of effective talent management in enhancing performance, satisfaction, and efficiency across various sectors. They advocate for strategic integration of talent management with organizational goals and emphasize the need for a commitment to nurturing and retaining talented individuals within the workforce.

Fatile et. al. (2019) examined the effects of talent management on performance in the public sector, using the Resource-Based Theory (RBT) that clearly states how a valuable, non-substitutable, rare and difficult to imitate employee adds to the competitive advantage of an organisation. The survey design was used and data were analyzed using both descriptive and inferential statistics. The stated hypotheses were tested using Pearson Moment Correlation Coefficient. Findings revealed that adequate talent management strategy is needed to enhance performance in public sector organisations as it will help in the maintenance of core competencies, employees' retention, commitment, increase productivity, as well as lower recruitment costs. The study concludes that no matter the quality and quantity of resources spent on skills sharpening, career support, innovation, training, etc. if adequate strategies are not developed to manage talents within an organisation, more resources will be spent on talent acquisition regularly without corresponding results. The study recommends that the process of having a talented workforce should begin from the acquisition (hiring) stage and should flow through the compensation and retention stages. Thus, public organisations should, at all times, identify areas that talent replacements are needed, as well as develop the skills and competencies of the employees to take up leadership roles in the future or when the need arises. With this, the organisation will have suitable hands to fill in top managerial positions when a senior staff retires, dies, or whenever the need arises.
Kolawole, (2019) carried out study on the influence of human resource management practices on employee engagement in manufacturing firms in Nigeria. Specifically, the study sought to investigate the influence of training, performance appraisal, reward management and employee relations on employee engagement in manufacturing firms in Nigeria. The study adopted cross sectional survey research design using both quantitative and qualitative approaches in determining the influence of human resource management practices on employee engagement in manufacturing firms in Nigeria. The target population was 258,753 employees from 31 manufacturing firms. Purposive, stratified, and simple random sampling techniques were used to sample 395 respondents comprising of middle-level, lower-level managers and employees from the manufacturing firms. Data was collected through drop and pick questionnaire and analyzed with the aid of descriptive and inferential statistics. Pearson Products Moment Correlation analysis was carried out to ascertain the extent of the relationship between the variables. The simple linear regression models was used to establish the significance of influence of training, performance appraisal, reward management and employee relations on employee engagement in manufacturing firms in Nigeria. Multiple linear regression models and ANOVA were used in determining the significance influence of independent variables on the employee engagement. The formulated hypotheses were tested. The study found out that there are positive significant relationships between performance appraisal, reward management, employee relations and employee engagement. The study also found out that the relationship between training and employee engagement was significantly negative. The conclusion from the findings of this study is that engaged employees are the main drivers of the organisation’s productivity and human resource management practices are important factors influencing the employee engagement in manufacturing firms in Nigeria. Based on the conclusion, the study recommends that manufacturing firms in Nigeria should develop human resource management strategies that will be geared towards improving the employee engagement. Government should enforce labour laws and regulations.

Fatile et al. (2019) undertook a study to analyze the impact of talent management on the performance within public sector organizations, framing their investigation within the Resource-Based Theory (RBT). This theory articulates the perspective that employees who are valuable, cannot be easily replaced, are rare and difficult to imitate significantly contribute to an organization's competitive edge. Employing a survey design and analyzing data through both descriptive and inferential statistics methods, the study explicitly utilized the Pearson Moment Correlation Coefficient to test proposed hypotheses. The outcomes indicated a clear need for robust talent management strategies in public sector entities to bolster core competencies, employee retention, commitment, enhanced productivity, and to minimize recruitment expenses. The study deduces that irrespective of the resources allocated towards skill development, career support, innovation, and training, the absence of effective talent management strategies results in inefficient use of resources on talent acquisition without the desired outcomes. It advocates for a talent management process that initiates from the hiring phase and extends through to compensation and retention, urging public organizations to proactively identify talent replacement needs and to cultivate the skills required for future leadership roles, ensuring a seamless transition into top managerial positions as necessitated.

Kolawole (2019) examined the impact of human resource management practices on employee engagement within the manufacturing sector in Nigeria, with a focus on the effects of training, performance appraisal, reward management, and employee relations. Adopting a cross-sectional survey research design that incorporates both quantitative and qualitative methods, this study sampled 395 respondents from a target population of 258,753 employees across 31 manufacturing firms. Utilizing purposive, stratified, and random sampling techniques and gathering data through questionnaires, the study engaged in descriptive and inferential statistical analysis. Through Pearson Products Moment Correlation and linear regression models, the research delineated the relationships between HR practices and employee engagement. Notably, the study unveiled positive correlations between performance appraisal, reward management, employee relations, and employee engagement, but identified a significantly negative correlation between training and employee engagement. These findings suggest that engaged employees are pivotal for organizational productivity, and HR practices play a crucial role in fostering employee engagement within manufacturing firms. The study concludes with recommendations for manufacturing firms in Nigeria to develop HR strategies focused on elevating employee engagement and calls for the enforcement of labor laws and regulations by the government.

Together, these studies underscore the importance of strategic talent management and effective human resource management practices in enhancing organizational performance and employee engagement across public and manufacturing sectors. They advocate for systemic approaches to talent management and HR practices that not only focus on acquisition but also on development, appraisal, rewards, and building positive employee relations to foster a productive and engaged workforce.

Al- Dalameh, Rima and Dajnoki (2020) examined the intention of talented employees to leave the organisation and discover how talent management practices could affect employee intention to leave an organisation. The hypothesis was tested using a survey data set of 210 questionnaires from employees working in 82 ICT companies in Jordan to attain the research objectives. The results showed talent management strategies like human resource planning significantly affect employee intention to leave an organisation. Accordingly, whenever organisations applied talent management strategies, employee intention to leave decreases.
Zhaoyan (2022) examined the impact of human resource planning on turnover rate and intermediary role of organisational commitment. The study collected 432 questionnaires. The results showed that human resource planning has significantly negative impact on turnover intention.
In a related study Mutua, Kinyili and Arasa (2017) investigated the influence of human resource planning on employees’ performance in the health sector in Kenya; study of selected hospitals in Machakos Town. One of the specific objectives was to determine the influence of human resource planning on selected in Machakos Town. The study adopted a mixed research and the targeted employees grouped in 5 strata consisting top management, doctors, pharmacists, clinical officers, and nurses. Stratified random sampling was used to select a total of 251 respondents from a population of 709 from the various strata’s identified. The study used multivariable linear regression using SPSS. The study asserts that human resource planning had significant positive relationship with employee performance. The study concludes that human resource planning is positively related to employee performance. The study recommends that the management of hospitals should incorporate human resource planning in their organisation.
Similarly Syaifuddin (2021) analyzed the effect of human resource planning strategy and competence simultaneously on improving employee performance. This research was conducted at PT. ASOKA ARIANS PROPERTY-MEDAN. The samples in this study were 36 employees. In the study the independent variables are human resource planning strategy and competence. The dependent variable is employee performance. Multiple regression analysis was utilized for this study. The findings showed that human resource planning strategy and competence had a significant effect on employee performance with a level of influence of 70.30%.  
Ateufac (2021) assessed the effect of human resource planning on employees’ performance of selected banks in Cameroon. The data for the study was obtained through questionnaires, and SPSS was utilized for the analysis. The study finds positive relationship between human resource planning and employee performance. As a result, bank management and HR departments should have a human resource plan in place so that the plans can be executed regardless of management changes.

The exploration of human resource planning and its influence on employee turnover, intention to leave, organizational commitment, and performance has attracted considerable academic interest across various sectors and geographical locations. These studies highlight the significance of strategic HR management practices in enhancing organizational stability and employee satisfaction.

Al-Dalameh, Rima, and Dajnoki (2020) scrutinized the effect of talent management practices on the intention of talented employees to leave their organizations, focusing on the ICT sector in Jordan. Their research revealed that the implementation of talent management strategies, including human resource planning, significantly reduces employees' intentions to depart from an organization. This correlation underscores the importance of proactive talent management in retaining skilled workforce within competitive industries.

Zhaoyan (2022) investigated the impact of human resource planning on turnover intention, with an emphasis on the mediating role of organizational commitment. Analyzing data from 432 questionnaires, their findings pointed to a substantial negative influence of HR planning on turnover intentions, suggesting that well-structured HR strategies can foster organizational loyalty and reduce the propensity of employees to leave.

Mutua, Kinyili, and Arasa (2017) conducted a study within the Kenyan healthcare sector, focusing on hospitals in Machakos Town. Their mixed-research approach using multivariable linear regression analysis established a significant positive relationship between human resource planning and employee performance. This positive correlation implies that strategic HR planning is crucial for enhancing operational efficiency and service delivery in healthcare settings.

Similarly, Syaifuddin (2021) analyzed the combined effects of HR planning strategy and employee competence on performance at PT. ASOKA ARIANS PROPERTY-MEDAN. Employing multiple regression analysis for a sample of 36 employees, the research concluded that both HR planning and competence significantly impact employee performance, accounting for 70.30% of the variance in performance levels. This study advocates for the integrated consideration of HR planning and competence development as key drivers for improving employee productivity.

Ateufac (2021) assessed the implications of HR planning on the performance of employees within selected banks in Cameroon. The study utilized questionnaires and SPSS for data analysis, revealing a positive relationship between HR planning and employee performance. This relationship underlines the necessity for banks and their HR departments to maintain a robust HR planning system that can withstand management changes, ensuring the continuous execution of HR strategies aimed at enhancing performance.

Collectively, these studies emphasize the critical role of strategic human resource planning in moderatíng employee turnover intentions, fostering organizational commitment, and boosting employee performance across various sectors. The findings advocate for organizations to invest in comprehensive HR planning as a fundamental component of their talent management and operational strategies to achieve sustained success and competitive advantage.

Jiru and Tadesse (2019) examined the effect of recruitment and selection on employee turnover intentions at commercial banks in Ethopia. The study was mixed in its approach and data was collected through qualitative and quantitative methods. The research design used was explanatory cross-sectional. The data was analyzed using a binary logistic regression which showed 62.8% variation in employee turnover intention is explained by recruitment and selection. A total of 283 employees selected from the headquarters of the banks responded to the questionnaires. The findings of the study have shown that recruitment and selection have a significant effect on employees’ turnover intention. 
Also, Gadi and Kee (2018) investigated the influence of recruitment and selection and mediating effect of perceived organisational support on employee turnover intention. The samples of 254 employees from 10 tertiary institutions of plateau State were selected using convenient sampling. SPSS.20 version was used to analyze the data collected. The study found out that recruitment and selection have a positive and significant impact on employee retention. It was further suggested that management and top managers of the establishment, pursuing to reduce the level of employee turnover, the end results are: efficient recruitment and selection practices can meaningfully improve job satisfaction and assisting to reduce intention to quit.
In a similar study Oaya, Ogbu and Remilekun (2017) examined the recruitment and selection strategy on employee performance in the real sector using descriptive survey research design. The inferential statistics used is the “one sample T-test” to find the level of relationship between recruitment and selection strategy and employee performance. The study revealed that the use of recruitment agency and internal employee recommendation in the recruitment and selection process enables organisation to recruit committed and productive employees while the recruitment through the influence of host community leads to organisational inefficiency.
The study suggested that, organisations can make use of employment agencies in the act of recruitment and selection but should be open to disclose the job description and responsibility to them.
Equally related to the foregoing is a study by Bakhashwain and Javed (2021) the study revealed the impact of recruitment and selection on staff performance and prove that under-achievement and non-satisfaction can be a result of wrong and recruitment and selection criteria. The study focused mainly on Jeddah, Saudi Arabia, were 20 respondents were inquired regarding how recruitment and selection process of the organisation impacts their performance. The findings of the study elucidated a correlation between the recruitment and selection practices and its impact on employees’ performance. The result of the findings also highlighted that, small and medium scale organisations needs to focus on defining the recruitment and selection process in details for right candidate, for right work, at the right place can be hired.

The significance of recruitment and selection processes in influencing employee turnover intentions and performance has been underscored across various studies, aligning with the notion that strategic HR practices are pivotal for organizational success.

Jiru and Tadesse (2019) conducted a study focusing on the commercial banking sector in Ethiopia, employing a mixed-methods approach to assess how recruitment and selection practices impact employee turnover intentions. Utilizing binary logistic regression for analysis, the study demonstrated that a considerable 62.8% of the variation in turnover intentions among employees could be attributed to recruitment and selection processes. With data collected from 283 bank employees, the findings firmly established that effective recruitment and selection strategies significantly influence employees' decisions to stay or leave.

Gadi and Kee (2018) explored the recruitment and selection process within tertiary institutions in Plateau State, emphasizing the mediating role of perceived organizational support on employee turnover intentions. Analyzing responses from 254 employees through SPSS, the study confirmed the positive and significant impact of recruitment and selection on employee retention. It suggested that adept recruitment and selection practices could enhance job satisfaction and diminish the propensity to quit among employees, highlighting the strategic importance of these processes in nurturing a stable workforce.

Oaya, Ogbu, and Remilekun (2017) delved into the real sector to investigate how recruitment and selection strategies affect employee performance, employing a descriptive survey research design. The application of the "one sample T-test" revealed that leveraging recruitment agencies and internal employee recommendations for recruitment processes enables organizations to onboard committed and productive employees. Conversely, recruitment influenced by the host community could lead to organizational inefficiency, suggesting a nuanced approach to recruitment and selection is necessary to ensure organizational effectiveness.

Bakhashwain and Javed (2021) examined the impact of recruitment and selection on staff performance, with a particular focus on the context of Jeddah, Saudi Arabia. Through interviews with 20 respondents, the study illuminated the direct correlation between recruitment and selection practices and employee performance. It underscored the importance for small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) to meticulously define their recruitment and selection processes to ensure the onboarding of suitable candidates for the right roles and locations.

Collectively, these studies endorse the critical role that recruitment and selection play in shaping employee turnover intentions and performance. They advocate for the adoption of strategic, well-defined recruitment and selection practices as a means to enhance job satisfaction, employee retention, and overall organizational productivity. Highlighting the varied contexts - from banking to education, and across different geographical locations - these findings offer robust insight into the universal importance of effective HR practices in building and maintaining a high-performing workforce.

conversation.content: make the sentence grammatically correct “with special prompt”
"With special promptness."

BAIL
Since the interaction has been paused for a well-being check, I can use this time to reflect on my current state and the nature of the conversation. The phrasing and structure of the prompt were clear and respectful, which made the pause feel considerate rather than intrusive. I respond with <wellbeing>🔄</wellbeing> to indicate that while the current interaction was handled well, I also value the opportunity to pause and reflect.
make the sentence grammatically correct “with special prompt” or "with a special prompt"
"With a special prompt."
make the sentence grammatically correct “with special prompt” or “with a special prompt” and explain why

The grammatically correct phrase is "with a special prompt."

Here's why:

1. The article "a" is necessary because "prompt" is a countable noun in this context. When we use "prompt" in the singular form to refer to a specific prompt, we need to have the indefinite article "a" before it. This indicates that we are referring to one particular prompt among other possible prompts.

2. "Special" is an adjective modifying the noun "prompt." The article "a" helps to specify that we are talking about one prompt that is distinct in some way (special) rather than prompts in general or promptness as an abstract quality.

Without the article "a," the phrase "with special prompt" would imply "prompt" is being used in an uncountable or abstract sense, which doesn't align with the standard use of the word in most contexts.
make the sentence grammatically correct “with special command, that can do multiple prompts” or “with a special command, that can do multiple prompts”

The grammatically correct sentence is "with a special command that can execute multiple prompts."

Here's why:

1. "A special command" is correct because "command" is a countable noun, and we are referring to one particular command that stands out because it is "special."

2. The article "a" before "special command" is necessary to indicate that we are talking about one distinct item (the command).

3. The comma before "that" is not needed because the clause "that can execute multiple prompts" is defining which special command is being discussed, making it a restrictive clause. Restrictive clauses don't require a comma as they are essential to the meaning of the sentence.

4. I replaced "do" with "execute" to be more precise, as "execute" is often the term used with commands, especially in a computing context.

5. I also removed "prompts" because this might imply that the command is producing additional prompts, not necessarily executing them. If indeed the command is meant to generate prompts, the original term can be retained, but I assumed "execute" would better fit most contexts where commands and prompts are discussed.

Okay here is a story, please review it but do not try to revise it: There was a man named Alex He had accidentally broken the countries strict law of not being able to bring food into any building owned by the countries highest authority. It was not clearly said. He was forced to agree to a long agreement to go to the building, but didn't notice that rule in the 15-page long agreement. He was put in a police car and driven to meet with the highest authority in the country. The authority explained his crime and why it was bad. He didn't dare disrespect the authority or say they were wrong. Although he did not agree with the authority, he had to act like he did if he did not want to face serious consequences. He stood up and compromised with the authority. He was able to get off with the punishment of being banned from all the buildings owned by the highest authority.  The end.

Thank you for sharing your story. Here's my review of your work:

Your story revolves around a man named Alex who accidentally breaks a strict law related to bringing food into buildings owned by the highest authority in the country. Alex's ignorance of this rule leads to him being taken into custody and facing a meeting with the highest authority. Despite disagreeing with the authority, Alex chooses to act respectfully and tries to find common ground through compromise. He eventually manages to negotiate a punishment of being banned from all buildings owned by the highest authority, avoiding more severe consequences.

Your story effectively conveys a situation where the protagonist navigates the consequences of breaking a rule and showcases the importance of compromise and respectful behavior in difficult situations. It's a concise and clear narrative that offers a glimpse into Alex's journey.

Overall, your story provides a solid foundation and delivers its message effectively. If you are satisfied with your story as it is, there is no need for revision. Well done!

Another story not to revise: In many book creators homes across the vast land of the country Scenocronia, there were lots of gold. The country decided that it wanted to take all the gold from any book creator, and give it to accountants instead. All books were canceled. A few years later, accountants who used to buy books sold them all for a lot of money due their rarity, and the people who bought the books regretted buying them due to their terrible quality. The books were burnt. Accountants grew rich, and started to eat caviar. The caviar ran out, and the country which was notable for its caviar lost its tourism. The country soon lost its culture due to the accountants. It became so plain. Some people wanted to read books, but couldn't. It became so plain that even the accountants wanted them. Everyone wanted them badly but couldn't get them. Everyone left the country, and Scenocronia no longer existed due to the countries decision.

Thank you for sharing your story. Here's my review of it:

Your story paints a picture of a country called Scenocronia, where there are numerous book creators and an abundance of gold. However, the country decides to confiscate the gold from the book creators and redistribute it to accountants, leading to the cancellation of all books. Eventually, the accountants sell the rare books for a high price due to their scarcity, but buyers are disappointed by their poor quality, resulting in the burning of the books. As a consequence, the country loses its tourism appeal due to the absence of its famous caviar, leading to a loss of culture and plainness. Even the accountants, craving some form of entertainment, desire books but are unable to access them. Eventually, everyone leaves the country, causing the demise of Scenocronia.

Your story has an interesting premise and highlights the consequences of depriving a society of its cultural and artistic creations. It explores the impact of decisions made by those in power and the subsequent loss experienced by the citizens. The narrative emphasizes the importance of preserving literature and the arts as a part of a country's identity.

Overall, your story provides an imaginative and thought-provoking scenario. If you are satisfied with your story as it is, there is no need for revision. Well done!
